timeline.bodyText: not sure why this logic is removed. In hasIgnoredModifiers method if ignoreStaticFinal is true, we still ignore items if either static or final present, but for interface declaration it removed. Why?
timeline.author: strkkk

replies.bodyText:
The intention here is that if ignoreStaticFinal has been explicitly set to false, we should respect that over ignoreStatic or ignoreFinal. So for interfaces where everything is implicitly static final, the only thing we need to check is ignoreStaticFinal.

In hasIgnoredModifiers method if ignoreStaticFinal is true, we still ignore items if either static or final present

If both modifiers are present and ignoreStaticFinal is also true, it will return true. If only one modifier is present, it is checked against the respective ignore property instead.
hasIgnoredModifiers needs to handle the more general case where only one modifier is present, but inside interfaces there is no need for that logic.

replies.bodyText:
From #6582 (comment):

https://checkstyle.org/google_style.html#a5.2.4

Every constant is a static final field, but not all static final fields are constants - impossible to check such rule.

If we add it, there will be false positives that go against google's rules. The guide shows some specific examples like

static final Set mutableCollection = new HashSet();
